730378f-a.title: General view - [Manhattan - Irving Place - 15th Street (Southeast).]
730378f-a.text:
A general view, south from irving Place, at the S.E. corner of 15th Street,between Third Ave., and Union Bquare East.
September 23, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.

720622f-a.text:
Irving Place, east side, north from East 15th Street.
November 25, 1935.
P. L. Sperr.

720621f-a.text:
14 to 22 Irving Place, at, adjoining and north of the N.E. corner of East 15th Street, showing a row of 4-story structures still used for residential purposes at this date.
December 9, 1937.
George D. Chinn.

711328f-a.text:
113-115 and 109-111 East 15th Street, north side, between Irving Place and Union Square East, showing respectively the Delehanty Institute and the former U.S. Brewers Association.
August, 1938
George D. Chinn

720615f-a.text:
Irving Place Iheatre, 11 Irving Place, Manhattan
Taken from north east corner of Irving Place and East
15th Street.
Federal Art Project
"Changing New York"
Berenice Abbott, photographer
Neg. No. 305
[Note: negative at Museum of the City of New York]
Code I A-2
Sept. 5, 1938

711327f-a.text:
117-119 East 15th Street, adjoining N.W. corner of Irving Place.
About 1911.

720623f.text:
Irving Place, at and adjoining the S.W. corner of East 15th Street (right), showing at the corner, the Irving Place Theatre. This structure was known as Amberg's Theatre in 1892, which opened here in 1888 and at which the Puenchener Company played on November 5, 1890. Upon this site formerly stood Irving Hall, opened December 20, 1860 for balls, lectures and concerts, and which was famous as a rendezvous for one faction of the Democratic party, to which it gave its name. Today (1938), this building is given over to Burlesque performances, a feature which aroused local interest when Judge Crain was District Attorney of Manhattan recently; this and adjoining property being in his family for years. A negative print accompanies this, forming a set of two.
About 1900.
Neg# 1748
